bestBHT.bht: Sailing from Troas, a strong southerly breeze carried them with a straight course to the island of Samothrace, where they anchored under its protection. Luke's precise use of nautical terms reflects his familiarity with sea life. The Lord works through humble means to manifest His power, and the beginning of Christ's kingdom embodies the humility of the cross. Christ's servants should not be discouraged by obstacles but continue forward, for even if they don't see immediate results, their faith will be strengthened, knowing that God has called them.

Henry Alford: The coincidence of their going to Samothrace also shews it: determining the wind to have been from the S. or S.S. E.
It is only a strong southerly breeze which will overcome the current southwards which runs from the Dardanelles by Tenedos.
They seem to have anchored N. of the lofty island of Samothrace, under its lee.
Jamieson-Fausset-Brown: Therefore loosing from Troas, we came—literally, 'ran.'
with a straight course—that is, 'ran before the wind.'
The wind must have set in strong from the south or south-southeast to bring them there so soon, as the current is strong in the opposite direction.
Albert Barnes: Loosing from Troas - Setting sail from this place."
To Samothracia - This was an island in the Aegean Sea not far from Thrace... an asylum for fugitives and criminals.
And the next day to Nepalese - This was a maritime city of Macedonia, near the borders of Thrace.
Marvin Vincent: Came with a straight course [ευθυδρομησαμεν] . Lit., we ran a straight course. A nautical term for sailing before the wind.
John Calvin: The Lord doth thus bring to pass his works under a base and weak kind, that his power may shine more clearly at length...
The beginnings of the kingdom of Christ should be so ordered, that they might taste [savor] of the humility of the cross.
The servants of Christ must wrestle with all lets, neither must they be discouraged, but go forward to-morrow, if this day there appear no fruit of their labor...
Philip Schaff: We came with a straight course to Samothracia, or ‘we ran with a straight course.’
Luke, observes Hackett, observes almost a technical precision in the use of such terms.
His account of the voyage to Rome shows a surprising familiarity with sea life.
Archibald T. Robertson: We made a straight course (ευθυδρομησαμεν). First aorist active indicative of compound verb ευθυδρομεω (in Philo) from adjective ευθυδρομος (in Strabo), running a straight course (ευθυσ, δρομος).
It is a nautical term for sailing before the wind.
The day following (τη επιουση). Locative case of time with ημερα (day) to be supplied (Acts 7:26; Acts 20:15; Acts 21:18; Acts 23:11).
John Gill: an island in the gulf of Pagasa
famous for the worship of the Cabiri, or chief deities of the Gentiles
the most holy ceremonies of Samothracia
John Wesley: We ran with a straight course — Which increased their confidence that God had called them.

bhtAttempts.bht: Setting sail from Troas, the wind from the south or south-southeast brought them with a straight course to the island of Samothrace. This nautical term for sailing before the wind demonstrates Luke's precise and intimate knowledge of sea life. The Lord orchestrates His works in seemingly insignificant ways so that His power can shine through, and the beginnings of His kingdom are marked by humility. The servants of Christ should not be discouraged if they do not immediately see fruit, but rather continue forward, wrestling with all obstacles. This straightforward voyage increased their confidence that God had called them.

Sailing from Troas, a strong southerly breeze carried them with a straight course to the island of Samothrace, where they anchored under its protection. Luke's precise use of nautical terms reflects his familiarity with sea life. The Lord works through humble means to manifest His power, and the beginning of Christ's kingdom embodies the humility of the cross. Christ's servants should not be discouraged by obstacles but continue forward, for even if they don't see immediate results, their faith will be strengthened, knowing that God has called them.

Sailing from Troas, they ran with a straight course to the island of Samothrace, guided by a strong southerly breeze. Luke's use of nautical language showcases his knowledge of sea life. The Lord often works through seemingly insignificant circumstances to reveal His power. The humble beginnings of Christ's kingdom reflect the essence of the cross. In their work for Christ, His servants must persevere and not be discouraged by obstacles, trusting that God's calling will bear fruit in due time.

Setting sail from Troas, they ran a straight course to the island of Samothrace, led by a strong southerly breeze. The use of nautical terms in Luke's account demonstrates his expertise in sea life. The Lord often reveals His power through humble beginnings, exemplified by the cross. In their service for Christ, His followers should press on despite challenges, not losing heart if immediate results are not seen. Confidence in God's calling is built as they navigate through obstacles and continue their journey.

Sailing from Troas, they ran with a straight course to Samothrace, propelled by a strong southerly breeze. Luke's use of nautical terminology reflects his familiarity with sea life. The Lord often orchestrates His work through seemingly insignificant means, allowing His power to shine through. The humble beginnings of Christ's kingdom reflect the essence of the cross. His servants should persevere and not grow discouraged by obstacles, but rather continue on, trusting in God's calling and His faithfulness to bring forth fruit in due time.
